title: Beautiful World Maps using R
text:
Do you want to learn how to create beautiful world maps using R programming?
In this video I show you how to download world map data, plot it, add texts and colors, and even change the map projection using the R packages {ggplot2} and {sf}.
Be sure to check it out:

title: Beautiful World Maps using R
text: Visualisations

title: How to Detect Emotions üòçüò≠üò± from Texts
text:
Would you like to know how to extract the main emotions from any text and visualize its emotional trajectory using the R programming language?
And learn this in a fun way?
In this new YouTube video, we will implement a simple-but-efficient method (a lexicon-based sentiment analysis) generally used to analyse consumer feedbacks, social medias or texts in surveys. But, to make it more fun, we will instead analyse the book Nineteen Eighty-Four from George Orwell.
Be sure to check out the video:

title: How to Detect Emotions üòçüò≠üò± from Texts
text: Visualisations

title: Interactive Network of the Marvel Universe
text:
Let‚Äôs have some fun creating an interactive network of the Marvel Cinematic Universe using R programming.
First we will scrape the data from Wikipedia, structure the data in a tidy way, and build an interactive network of the main Marvel characters.
You can play with the final interactive network here.
Learn how to make it by yourself watching the video:

title: Interactive Network of the Marvel Universe
text: Visualisation

title: Swiss City Statistics
text:
The Application
Choose an indicator, two cities, and have fun trying to guess which city has the highest indicator value.



Data Info
The Swiss City Statistics dataset contains +400 indicators about 9 Swiss cities and their agglomerations.
The data is queried using the BFS R package.

title: F√©lix Luginb√ºhl
text:
LinkedIn
  
  
    
     Youtube
  
  
    
     GitHub
  
  
    
     Substack

üëã Hi there!


My name is F√©lix Luginb√ºhl. I‚Äôm a Data Scientist and R Developer. I build tools and apps (mostly with R) to automate data analysis, share insights and improve decision making.

title: F√©lix Luginb√ºhl
text:
Get the code
Join my newsletter to download all the R scripts of my blog posts and YouTube videos.


Once you subscribed you will receive an automatic email with the URL of my GitHub repository, where you can download all the code.

title: F√©lix Luginb√ºhl
text:
Let‚Äôs do something together!

  
    Web apps
  
  
    Automated reports
  
  
    R Training
  


  
    Get insightful and fully customized web applications. I build engaging and interactive dashboards, which centralize your insights and data with zero software licensing costs attached.
    Examples ‚Üí
  
  
    Automate documents and data workflows. From data extraction to report generation, data analysis are generated in seconds rather than days. It can be a game changer for your decision-making process.
    Examples ‚Üí
  
  
    Learn R programming and make the most of your data. I regularly publish YouTube videos and blog posts to teach you data analytics with R. Learn R to liberate you from Excel and expensive softwares.
    Examples ‚Üí
  

If you‚Äôre interested in working with me, please contact me on LinkedIn.

title: Advanced Data Filtering in R using dplyr
text:
In this video I show you advanced uses of the filter() function from the dplyr R package.
We will see different ways of keeping or removing specific rows of a dataset using 5 simple examples. Then we will explore more advanced filtering methods, such as filtering data using logical conditions on multiple columns, how to remove missing values or how to use specific words or strings to filter rows of character variables.

title: Read, Clean and Merge Excel files using R
text:
Do you want to know how to create R loops that read hundreds of Excel files into R?
And that your R loops clean, validate and even merge your Excel files data into a single and consolidated dataset?
Well, you are lucky‚Ä¶ My new video just teaches you how to do that üòâ. And in only 5 minutes. So be sure to check it out:

title: Google Sheet Automation using R
text:
Would you like to learn how to connect R to your Google Drive and automate the data processing of your Google Sheets?
I just published a new YouTube video showing the basics of working with Google Sheets data using R programming.
You will learn how to:

Connect R to Google Drive and list your existing Sheets.
Write and read Google Sheets from R.
Append data to a Google Sheet.
Rename a worksheet.
Change file access permission (from private to public).

Check it out:

title: Interactive Country Maps with R
text:
Would you like to learn how to create interactive maps of any European country at a district level using R?
In this new YouTube video I show you how to map Switzerland at a regional level using Eurostat geodata. But these steps can be used for any European country.
You will learn how to:
Check out the video now:

title: Interactive Country Maps with R
text: Visualisation

title: Map ANY region of the world using R
text:
Would you like to learn how to create beautiful maps of any region of the world using the R programming language?
I just published a new YouTube video showing you how to create a choropleth world map using World Bank unemployment data, and how to zoom on any specific region. As an example, we will visualize the European region only.
But of course, you can reuse the R code showed in the video with your own dataset on any region of your choice.
At the end of the video I discuss some important points regarding the use of the scale and the color palette when creating a map, so be sure to watch the video until the end.

title: Customized Leaflet map using R
text:
Would you like to know how to customize interactive maps using leaflet with R programming?
In this new YouTube video I show you how to fully customize your leaflet maps. As an example I reproduce an Swiss official choropleth map of Switzerland showing the top 5 most common surnames by commune.
You will learn how to:
Sounds interesting? Check out the video now:

title: BFS R package - Search and download data from the Swiss Federal Statistical Office
text: The BFS R package allows to explore and access Swiss public data in a dynamic and reproducible way. Users can discover the latest BFS datasets available, extract their metadata and download them in any language (German, French, Italian or English) directly from the R console.

title: BFS R package - Search and download data from the Swiss Federal Statistical Office
text: The BFS R package allows to explore and access Swiss public data in a dynamic and reproducible way. Users can discover the latest BFS datasets available, extract their metadata and download them in any language (German, French, Italian or English) directly from the R console.

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
About me

Currently supporting the R tranformation of the Statistical Office of St.Gallen.
Worked 2 years as Data Scientist at the Global Fund.
Background in social sciences (Master in Sociology and Master in European Studies from the University of Geneva).

Disclamer: I am a self-trained R mapper!2
Online presence: felixluginbuhl.com, github.com/lgnbhl.

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
How to access geodata?
International level:

The Natural Earth Project (public domain).

European level:

Gisco: Eurostat Mapping API.

Country level (Switzerland):

Swiss national geoportal (geo.admin.ch)
Official Thematic Base Maps (ThemaKart)

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
International geodata
Get world data from the Natural Earth Project.
```r .smaller #| echo: true #install.packages(‚Äúrnaturalearth‚Äù) library(rnaturalearth) library(ggplot2) library(sf)
world <- ne_countries(returnclass = ‚Äúsf‚Äù)
ggplot(world) + geom_sf() + theme_minimal()

## International geodata

You also can access physical geodata with `ne_download()`.

```r
#| echo: true
rivers50 <- ne_download(
  scale = 50,
  type = "rivers_lake_centerlines",
  category = "physical",
  returnclass = "sf")

ggplot(rivers50) +
  geom_sf() +
  theme_minimal()

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
International geodata
Get national data with ‚Äúcountry‚Äù argument (‚Äúgeounit‚Äù for metropolitan only):
#| echo: true
swiss <- ne_countries(
  country = "switzerland", 
  scale = 10, #1:10m 
  returnclass = "sf")

ggplot(swiss) +
  geom_sf() +
  theme_minimal()

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
International geodata
Get ‚Äústate‚Äù (cantonal) level data with ne_states().
#| echo: true
swiss_cantons <- ne_states(
  country = "switzerland", 
  returnclass = "sf")

ggplot(swiss_cantons) +
  geom_sf() +
  theme_minimal()

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
European geodata
Access Eurostat Mapping API.
#| echo: true
library(giscoR)
library(ggplot2)

switzerland_sf <- gisco_get_nuts(
  country = "Switzerland", 
  nuts_level = 3, #Counties/provinces/districts
  resolution = "01") #1:1million

ggplot(switzerland_sf) +
  geom_sf() +
  theme_minimal()

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Switzerland geodata
Swiss national geoportal (Swiss Stac API) with bfs_get_catalog_geodata().
#| echo: true
library(BFS)
library(dplyr) # for glimpse()

#bfs_download_geodata() #download by collection_id
bfs_get_catalog_geodata(include_metadata = FALSE) |> glimpse()

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Switzerland geodata


The ThemaKart project gives access to various thematic maps.


A typical base maps ThemaKart file looks like this:

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Switzerland geodata
You can access base maps files with bfs_get_base_maps().
#| echo: true
# list of geometry names: https://www.bfs.admin.ch/asset/en/24025645
switzerland_sf <- bfs_get_base_maps(geom = "suis")
communes_sf <- bfs_get_base_maps(geom = "polg", date = "20230101")
districts_sf <- bfs_get_base_maps(geom = "bezk")
cantons_sf <- bfs_get_base_maps(geom = "kant")
cantons_capitals_sf <- bfs_get_base_maps(geom = "stkt", type = "Pnts", category = "kk")
lakes_sf <- bfs_get_base_maps(geom = "seen", category = "11")

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Switzerland static map with ggplot2
#| echo: true
library(ggplot2)

ggplot() + 
  geom_sf(data = communes_sf, fill = "snow", color = "grey45") + 
  geom_sf(data = lakes_sf, fill = "lightblue2", color = "black") +
  geom_sf(data = districts_sf, fill = "transparent", color = "grey65") + 
  geom_sf(data = cantons_sf, fill = "transparent", color = "black") +
  geom_sf(data = cantons_capitals_sf, shape = 18, size = 3) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text = element_blank()) +
  labs(caption = "Source: ThemaKart, ¬© BFS")

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Joining data to Swiss geodata
Each observation of your data should be joined to a geodata spatial geometry.
The sf R package (for ‚ÄúSimple Feature‚Äù) allows to do it in a tidy way.
#| echo: true
library(BFS)

bfs_get_base_maps(geom = "kant") |> glimpse()

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Joining data to Swiss geodata
Let‚Äôs download an official Swiss dataset with BFS:
r, results = 'hide' #| echo: true #bfs_get_catalog_data() # get catalog # Swiss dataset: https://www.bfs.admin.ch/asset/de/px-x-1502000000_101 swiss_students <- BFS::bfs_get_data(   number_bfs = "px-x-1502000000_101",    language = "fr",    clean_names = TRUE)
glimpse(swiss_students)

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Joining data to Swiss geodata
We can then pivot it and calculate share of female students:
#| echo: true
library(tidyverse)

swiss_students_gender <- swiss_students |>
  filter(nationalite_categorie == "Suisse", #only Swiss students
         canton_de_lecole != "Suisse") |> #only cantonal data
  pivot_wider(names_from = sexe, values_from = eleves_et_etudiants) |>
  mutate(share_woman = round(Femme/`Sexe - Total`*100, 1))

glimpse(swiss_students_gender)

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Joining data to Swiss geodata
We can then joining our data to the geodata.
#| echo: true
swiss_map <- bfs_get_base_maps(geom = "kant")

dplyr::setdiff(swiss_map$name, unique(swiss_students_gender$canton_de_lecole))

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Joining data to Swiss geodata
We need to do some recoding before the left join.
#| echo: true
swiss_student_map <- swiss_students_gender %>%
  filter(canton_de_lecole != "Schweiz") %>% # remove national level
  mutate(canton_de_lecole = str_remove(canton_de_lecole, ".*/"),
         canton_de_lecole = str_trim(canton_de_lecole),
         canton_de_lecole = recode(canton_de_lecole, "Berne" = "Bern", "Freiburg" = "Fribourg", "Grischun" = "Graub√ºnden", "Ticino" = "Tessin", "Wallis" = "Valais")) |>
  left_join(swiss_map, by = c("canton_de_lecole" = "name")) |>
  select(canton_de_lecole, annee, degre_de_formation, share_woman, geometry)

glimpse(swiss_student_map)

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Interactive Maps with mapview

mapview provides functions to very quickly and conveniently create interactive visualisations of spatial data. It‚Äôs main goal is to fill the gap of quick (not presentation grade) interactive plotting to examine and visually investigate both aspects of spatial data, the geometries and their attributes. It can also be considered a data-driven API for the leaflet package as it will automatically render correct map types, depending on the type of the data (points, lines, polygons, raster).

Source: https://r-spatial.github.io/mapview/

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Interactive Maps with mapview
The easy way with mapview (but limited customization).
#| echo: true
library(BFS)
library(mapview)

bfs_get_base_maps(geom = "bezk") |>
  mapview(zcol = "name", legend = FALSE)

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
How to Create Interactive Maps with R
How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Interactive Maps with mapview
mapview is using Leaflet in the background, which allows to access extra functionality:
#| echo: true
library(leafsync)

sync(map_2023, map_2000)

mapview is using Leaflet in the background, which allows to access extra functionality:

map_2023 | map_2000

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Interactive Maps with leaflet
Let‚Äôs reproduce this datawrapper map:

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Interactive Maps with leaflet
Let‚Äôs find the data with bfs_get_catalog_tables().
#| echo: true
tables_names <- BFS::bfs_get_catalog_tables(
  language = "en", 
  title = "last+names")

glimpse(tables_names)

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R

text:
Interactive Maps with leaflet
Let‚Äôs download and read the data.
#| echo: true
glimpse(df)

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
How to Create Interactive Maps with R
How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Interactive Maps with leaflet
#| echo: true
create_table(name = "Aadorf")

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Interactive Maps with leaflet
Get official Swiss base maps.
#| echo: true
communes_sf <- BFS::bfs_get_base_maps(geom = "polg")
lakes_sf <- BFS::bfs_get_base_maps(geom = "seen", category = "11") |>
  sf::st_transform(crs = "+proj=longlat +datum=WGS84")

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Interactive Maps with leaflet
Create a basic leaflet map.
#| echo: true
library(leaflet)

# customize legend 
bins = c(0, 1, 2.5, 5, 10, 20, 100)
col_custom = c("#f5b3bb", "#ef8894","#e85767","#dc0018","#a60013","#73000d")
pal <- colorBin(col_custom, 
                domain = sf_communes_joined$PCT_GDE, 
                bins = bins)
legend_labels <- c("0 ‚Äì 1", "1 ‚Äì 2.5", "2.5 ‚Äì 5", 
                   "5 ‚Äì 10", "10 ‚Äì 20", "20 ‚Äì 100")

map <- leaflet(sf_communes_joined, height = 600, width = 900) |>
  addPolygons(
    weight = 0.3,
    opacity = 1,
    color = "white",
    fillOpacity = 1,
    fillColor = ~pal(PCT_GDE),
    label = ~lapply(table, htmltools::HTML),
  ) |>
  addPolygons(
    data = lakes_sf, 
    label = ~name,
    stroke = FALSE,
    color = "gray70"
    ) |> 
  addLegend(
    title = "Share of the most<br>common surname, in %", 
    labFormat = function(type, cuts, p) { paste0(legend_labels) },
    values = ~PCT_GDE,
    pal = pal, 
    opacity = 1
  )

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Interactive Maps with leaflet
Create a basic leaflet map.
#| echo: true
map

Adding bounding box, empty background and fix zooming.

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Interactive Maps with leaflet
Add map in a card with title and legend.
#| echo: true
library(bslib)
library(htmltools)

card <- card(
  tags$h5("The Five Most Frequent Last Names by Commune, 2022"),
  tags$i("Hover to display the five most common surnames (actual number and percentage) by commune."),
  map,
  tags$p(
    "Source: FSO ‚Äì STATPOP, inspired by:", 
    tags$a("https://www.bfs.admin.ch/asset/en/27205601", 
           href = "https://www.bfs.admin.ch/asset/en/27205601")),
  tags$p("Get the R code:", 
         tags$a("felixanalytix.com",
                href = "https://felixanalytix.com")),
  min_height = 800, 
  max_height = 800
)

title: How to Create Interactive Maps with R
text:
Interactive Maps with leaflet
Add map in a card with title and legend.
#| echo: true
card
